This is happening when a request is made, and the system is trying to authenticate the user.

The issue is likely in your `UserDetailServiceImpl` class where the `loadUserByUsername` method is called but can't find the user in the database. Let's fix this by improving the error handling in that method:

<augment_code_snippet path="src/main/java/org/example/Service/UserDetailServiceImpl.java" mode="EDIT">
```java
@Override
public UserDetails loadUserByUsername(String username) throws UsernameNotFoundException {
 UsersEntity user = userRepository.findByUsername(username);
 if(user == null){
 // Add more descriptive error message with the username that wasn't found
 throw new UsernameNotFoundException("User not found: " + username);
 }
 return new CustomUserDetails(user);
}
```
</augment_code_snippet>

You should also check if:

1. The user 'Tushar' actually exists in your database
2. The username case matches exactly (e.g., 'tushar' vs 'Tushar')
3. There are no extra spaces in the username when it's being sent

If you're testing the API, make sure you're sending the correct username in your request body.

this is comming null even tho the username is there in the database","rich_text_json_repr":{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" UsersEntity user = userRepository.findByUsername(username);"},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"this is comming null even tho the username is there in the database"}]}]},"mentioned_items":[],"structured_output_nodes":[{"id":0,"type":0,"content":"If `userRepository.findByUsername(username)` is returning null even though the username exists in the database, there are a few potential issues to check:

1. The most common issue is case sensitivity. Your database might be storing "Tushar" but you're searching for "tushar" (or vice versa).

2. Let's modify the repository method to be case-insensitive:

<augment_code_snippet path="src/main/java/org/example/Repository/UserRepository.java" mode="EDIT">
```java
public interface UserRepository extends CrudRepository<UsersEntity, Long> {
 // Case-insensitive username search
 UsersEntity findByUsernameIgnoreCase(String username);
}
```
</augment_code_snippet>

Then update your service to use this method:

<augment_code_snippet path="src/main/java/org/example/Service/UserDetailServiceImpl.java" mode="EDIT">
```java
@Override
public UserDetails loadUserByUsername(String username) throws UsernameNotFoundException {
 UsersEntity user = userRepository.findByUsernameIgnoreCase(username);
 if(user == null){
 throw new UsernameNotFoundException("User not found: " + username);
 }
 return new CustomUserDetails(user);
}
```
</augment_code_snippet>

3. If that doesn't work, there might be a mismatch between the username field in your DTO and entity. Looking at your code, I notice:

<augment_code_snippet path="src/main/java/org/example/model/UsereEntityDto.java" mode="EXCERPT">
```java
public class UsereEntityDto extends UsersEntity {
 private String userName; // Note: this is camelCase "userName"
 // ...
}
```
</augment_code_snippet>

But in your signup method, you're using:

<augment_code_snippet path="src/main/java/org/example/Service/UserDetailServiceImpl.java" mode="EXCERPT">
```java
userRepository.save(new UsersEntity(userId, user.getUsername(), user.getPassword(), new HashSet<>()));
```
</augment_code_snippet>

There's a potential mismatch between `userName` in the DTO and `username` in the entity. Let's fix the signup method:

<augment_code_snippet path="src/main/java/org/example/Service/UserDetailServiceImpl.java" mode="EDIT">
```java
public Boolean signup(UsereEntityDto user) throws IOException {
 // Use the correct field from the DTO
 user.setPassword(passwordEncoder.encode(user.getPassword()));
 
 // Create a new entity with the correct username field
 UsersEntity newUser = new UsersEntity();
 newUser.setUsername(user.getUserName()); // Use getUserName() from DTO
 newUser.setPassword(user.getPassword());
 newUser.setUserId(UUID.randomUUID().toString());
 newUser.setRoles(new HashSet<>());
 
 // Check if user exists using the correct username
 if(Objects.nonNull(userRepository.findByUsername(newUser.getUsername()))){
 return false;
 }
 
 userRepository.save(newUser);
 return true;
}
```
</augment_code_snippet>

This should resolve the mismatch between your DTO and entity fields.
